deliberation: Checked for non-literal phrases in the prophetic introduction. The standard formula 'the word of YHWH came to me' personifies God's word as an entity that comes, which is a conventional metaphor/idiom for prophetic revelation.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
vehicle: a moving 'word' that comes to a person
ground: initiative and directed movement from sender to recipient
posture: underscoring authority and divine origin of the message
instances.explanation: God’s communication is depicted as a ‘word’ that actively comes to the prophet, personifying and metaphorically spatializing revelation.

deliberation: Looked for figurative designations of Jerusalem and any personification. Found the epithet 'city of bloodshed' and the treatment of the city as a person to whom one can declare charges.

instances.english_text: the city of bloodshed
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is labeled 'city of bloodshed', metonymically identifying it with the murders committed there and metaphorically characterizing it as essentially murderous.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲתִשְׁפֹּט אֶת־עִיר הַדָּמִים וְהוֹדַעְתָּהּ אֵת כׇּל־תּוֹעֲבוֹתֶיהָ
instances.english_text: arraign the city of bloodshed; declare to her all her abhorrent deeds
target: Jerusalem (its people) as addressed in judgment
vehicle: a person summoned to court and informed of charges
ground: accountability, being formally charged, having crimes recited
posture: framing God’s judgment as a courtroom indictment
instances.explanation: The city (its inhabitants) is personified as a defendant in court, being judged and having her abominations formally announced.

deliberation: Considered whether descriptions of bloodshed and idols are purely literal. The key figurative element is attributing the act of shedding blood to the 'city' itself (city for inhabitants), a metonymic personification.

instances.english_text: O city in whose midst blood is shed
vehicle: a city that actively sheds blood
ground: widespread killing attributed to the community as a whole
instances.explanation: The city is described as if it itself sheds blood, personifying Jerusalem and using 'city' metonymically for its inhabitants engaged in violence.

deliberation: Most elements are straightforward cause-and-effect. The notable figurative phrase is 'you have brought on your day; you have reached your year', using temporal imagery for the time of judgment approaching.

instances.english_text: You have brought on your day; you have reached your year
vehicle: a personal 'day' and 'year' one can draw near and arrive at
time as a boundary or appointment
ground: a fixed moment that comes inevitably and can be hastened by one’s actions
posture: warning that their own sins have hastened judgment
instances.explanation: Jerusalem’s time of judgment is portrayed as ‘her day/year’ that she herself has drawn near, an idiomatic metaphor for bringing about one’s own doom.

deliberation: Looked for merism, metaphor, and evaluative language. Found a merism in 'near and far' and a metaphor in 'defiled of name' where 'name' stands for reputation and is treated like a ritually polluted object.

instances.english_text: both the near and the far from you
ground: inclusion of all in-between by naming the extremes
posture: stressing that mockery will be universal
instances.explanation: The phrase 'the near and the far' functions as a merism, naming extremes of distance to indicate that all surrounding peoples will mock Jerusalem.

instances.english_text: O besmirched of name
vehicle: a name that has become ritually unclean or filthy
ground: loss of purity and honor, becoming offensive in others’ eyes
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is described as 'defiled of name', using 'name' metonymically for reputation and picturing it as something ritually polluted.

deliberation: Assessed the phrase 'each according to his arm' (אִישׁ לִזְרֹעוֹ). This is a common idiom where 'arm' stands metaphorically for strength or power.

instances.english_text: every one of the princes of Israel in your midst used his strength (lit. was 'according to his arm')
ground: ability to exert force, to control and overpower others
posture: criticizing abuse of power for violence
instances.explanation: The phrase uses 'arm' metonymically and metaphorically for personal power and capacity, an idiom indicating that each ruler used his strength to shed blood.

deliberation: Most actions (cheated, wronged) are literal. The phrase 'they have made father and mother light' is an idiom for treating parents with contempt.

instances.english_text: Fathers and mothers have been humiliated within you (lit. 'they made father and mother light')
ground: treating as of little weight or worth, despising
posture: condemning the community’s lack of honor for parents
instances.explanation: The idiom 'to make light' of someone metaphorically depicts dishonoring parents by treating them as of little weight or importance.

deliberation: Considered whether 'despised My holy things' and 'profaned My sabbaths' are figurative. These are standard covenant/ritual terms describing literal cultic violations, not clearly used as separate metaphors beyond their technical sense here.

Checked slander and bloodshed language (largely literal). The phrase 'they have eaten on the mountains' is a known idiom for participation in illicit high-place cults, using 'eating' and 'mountains' metonymically.

instances.english_text: in you they have eaten on the mountains
vehicle: eating sacrificial meals on high places
ground: sharing in meals as fellowship with a deity, using high places for such rites
instances.explanation: The phrase idiomatically denotes participation in high-place idolatry, with 'eating on the mountains' standing for those cultic practices.

deliberation: Identified the Levitical sexual-law idiom 'to uncover nakedness' as figurative for sexual relations, particularly with a forbidden relative.

instances.english_text: In you they have uncovered their fathers’ nakedness
target: sexual sin with a father’s wife
ground: violation of privacy and boundaries, sexual exposure
posture: branding the act as shameful and taboo
instances.explanation: The idiom 'uncover nakedness' metaphorically refers to illicit sexual intercourse, here specifically with the father’s wife.

deliberation: The sexual sins are mostly described literally. The key figurative element is the use of 'defile' (טִמֵּא) in a moral/ritual metaphor for the effect of their depravity.

instances.english_text: in their depravity they have defiled their own daughters-in-law
target: moral state of the offenders and their relationships
vehicle: ritual defilement of a formerly clean object
ground: loss of purity, becoming unfit for contact with the holy
posture: portraying sexual sin as spiritual pollution
instances.explanation: Sexual depravity is described in purity language as 'defiling' others, a metaphor that treats sin as a contaminating impurity.

deliberation: Economic wrongdoing is literal. The phrase 'you have forgotten Me' is stock covenant language where forgetfulness stands metaphorically for willful disregard and disloyalty.

instances.english_text: You have forgotten Me
target: Israel’s covenant relationship and loyalty to God
ground: failure to keep someone in mind, acting without reference to them
posture: accusing them of deliberate covenant disloyalty
instances.explanation: God depicts their disloyalty as 'forgetting' Him, an idiomatic metaphor for living and acting as though He were not present or significant.

deliberation: Looked for bodily-action idioms. 'I have struck My hand/palm' is a known gesture idiom expressing shock or rage, used anthropomorphically of God.

instances.english_text: I will strike My hands over the ill-gotten gains that you have amassed
target: God’s emotional response to Israel’s unjust gain
vehicle: striking one’s hands together in frustration or anger
posture: communicating God’s shock and anger at their blood-guilt and greed
instances.explanation: God is portrayed as clapping or striking His hands in anger over their unjust gain, an anthropomorphic idiom signaling vehement indignation.

deliberation: Examined 'heart stand' and 'hands be strong' for metaphor. Both use body imagery for inner courage and ability to endure judgment.

instances.english_text: Will your courage endure (lit. 'will your heart stand'), will your hands remain firm
target: Jerusalem’s inner resolve and actual capacity to endure judgment
vehicle: a heart that stands and hands that remain strong
stable bodily posture and muscular strength
ground: inner stability and capability likened to physical firmness and standing
posture: challenging their presumed resilience against God’s action
instances.explanation: The prophet uses heart and hands as metaphors for courage and strength, asking if their 'heart will stand' and their 'hands be strong' when God acts.

deliberation: Exile language is largely literal. The phrase 'I will consume your impurity out of you' treats impurity as something that can be destroyed/removed by judgment, a metaphorical purification image.

instances.english_text: I will consume the impurity out of you
vehicle: impurity as something that can be consumed/annihilated
foreign substance to be burned away
ground: judgment removes the offending element, leaving what is purified
instances.explanation: Their sins are portrayed as 'impurity' that God will 'consume' from them, a metaphor of purification through severe judgment.

deliberation: The verse speaks of dishonor before nations and knowing YHWH. These follow standard covenant/judgment idioms but are not themselves clearly figurative beyond their normal semantic range here.
Same prophetic formula as v.1, again personifying the divine word as something that 'comes' to the prophet.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
ground: directed approach from God to prophet, initiating speech
posture: asserting divine origin and authority of the oracle
instances.explanation: Again portrays God’s message as a 'word' that comes to the prophet, a conventional personifying metaphor for revelation.

deliberation: This verse is built around a strong metaphor: the house of Israel has become 'dross' and is identified with base metals within a crucible. This compares the people’s moral state to worthless metal waste.

instances.hebrew_text: הָיוּ־לִי בֵית־יִשְׂרָאֵל לְסִיג כֻּלָּם נְחֹשֶׁת וּבְדִיל וּבַרְזֶל וְעוֹפֶרֶת בְּתוֹךְ כּוּר סִגִים כֶּסֶף הָיוּ
instances.english_text: the House of Israel has become dross to Me; they are all copper, tin, iron, and lead, [the] dross in a crucible
target: the people of Israel in their current spiritual-moral state
vehicle: dross and base metals in a smelting furnace
ground: lack of purity and value, requiring intense heat to refine or discard
posture: devaluing Israel in God’s assessment and preparing for a refining-judgment image
instances.explanation: Israel is metaphorically described as dross and base metals in a crucible, highlighting their impurity and worthlessness in God’s eyes.

deliberation: Continues the dross metaphor; 'because you have all become dross' again treats the people as that waste metal to justify gathering them into Jerusalem for smelting-judgment.

instances.english_text: Because you have all become dross
ground: impurity and lack of value, fit only for burning or removal
posture: justifying severe judgment as treatment of valueless dross
instances.explanation: Again portrays the people as 'dross', extending the refining metaphor to explain why God will gather them for fiery judgment.

deliberation: This verse explicitly uses a comparative 'as... so' structure, likening the gathering and melting of metals in a crucible to God’s gathering and melting of the people in His wrath. Clear simile based on the refining image.

instances.hebrew_text: קְבֻצַת כֶּסֶף וּנְחֹשֶׁת וּבַרְזֶל וְעוֹפֶרֶת וּבְדִיל אֶל־תּוֹךְ כּוּר לָפַחַת־עָלָיו אֵשׁ לְהַנְתִּיךְ כֵּן אֶקְבֹּץ בְּאַפִּי וּבַחֲמָתִי וְהִנַּחְתִּי וְהִתַּכְתִּי אֶתְכֶם
instances.english_text: As silver, copper, iron, lead, and tin are gathered into a crucible to blow the fire upon them so as to melt them, so will I gather you in My fierce anger and cast you [into the fire] and melt you
vehicle: metals gathered into a crucible and melted by fire
ground: being subjected to intense heat leading either to purification or destruction
posture: threatening a consuming, refining judgment on the people
instances.explanation: God explicitly compares His gathering and 'melting' of the people in wrath to metals being gathered into a furnace and melted by fire.

deliberation: Continues the furnace imagery in metaphorical, not comparative form: God will blow His wrath like fire and they will be 'melted' in it, extending the smelting metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָפַחְתִּי עֲלֵיכֶם בְּאֵשׁ עֶבְרָתִי וְנִתַּכְתֶּם בְּתוֹכָהּ
instances.english_text: I will blow upon you the fire of My fury, and you shall be melted in it
target: experience of divine judgment by Israel
vehicle: stoking a furnace with bellows so that metal melts
ground: God’s wrath intensifies like a blast of air on a fire, leading to a melting outcome for the object
posture: depicting judgment as an inescapable, consuming furnace
instances.explanation: God’s 'fire of fury' is depicted like the blast that fuels a furnace, so that the people are 'melted', extending the refining-furnace metaphor.

deliberation: Two key figures: explicit simile 'as silver is melted in a crucible' and the image of God 'pouring out' His wrath, treating wrath as a liquid.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּהִתּוּךְ כֶּסֶף בְּתוֹךְ כּוּר כֵּן תֻּתְּכוּ בְתוֹכָהּ
instances.english_text: As silver is melted in a crucible, so shall you be melted in it
vehicle: silver being melted in a crucible
ground: subjected to intense fire that radically changes the material, separating pure from impure
instances.explanation: Their experience under God’s wrath is likened to silver being melted in a furnace, continuing the refining simile.

instances.english_text: I have poured out My fury upon you
target: God’s expression of anger in judgment
ground: wrath distributed in abundance and irreversibly, like a liquid being emptied out on something
posture: stressing fullness and decisiveness of wrath
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is pictured as a liquid poured out on them, a common metaphor and idiom for fully unleashing judgment.

deliberation: Again repeats the prophetic formula of the divine word 'coming' to Ezekiel, a conventional personifying metaphor.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
ground: God’s initiative and active approach toward the prophet
posture: affirming the divine source of what follows
instances.explanation: Uses the standard prophetic idiom of God’s 'word' coming to the prophet, personifying revelation as an approaching entity.

deliberation: The land is addressed as 'not cleansed' and 'not rained upon in the day of indignation'. 'Not cleansed' applies ritual purity language to the land itself, personifying it as morally defiled.

instances.english_text: You are an unpurified land
ground: saturated with bloodshed and sin, requiring cleansing
posture: personifying the land as morally polluted and under judgment
instances.explanation: The land is addressed as 'not cleansed', applying ritual impurity imagery and personifying the territory as defiled by its inhabitants’ sins.

deliberation: Detected explicit simile 'like a roaring lion tearing prey' for the prophets, and metaphor 'they devour souls' for their exploitation of people.

instances.hebrew_text: קֶשֶׁר נְבִיאֶיהָ בְּתוֹכָהּ כַּאֲרִי שׁוֹאֵג טֹרֵף טָרֶף
instances.english_text: Her gang of prophets are like roaring lions in her midst, rending prey
ground: ferocity, predatory behavior, causing terror and destruction among weaker ones
posture: strongly condemning the prophets as predatory and destructive
instances.explanation: The prophets’ oppressive behavior is likened to roaring lions tearing prey, a vivid simile casting them as predators.

instances.english_text: They devour human beings (lit. 'souls they have eaten')
target: lives and well-being of the people
ground: utterly consuming and destroying others for one’s own benefit
posture: depicting the prophets’ exploitation as life-destroying consumption
instances.explanation: By saying they 'eat souls', Ezekiel uses consumption as a metaphor for how the prophets destroy and exploit people’s lives.

deliberation: Most actions (violated, profaned, not distinguished) are technical/legal. The figurative element is 'have hidden their eyes from My sabbaths', an idiom for deliberate disregard.

instances.english_text: and they have closed their eyes to My sabbaths
vehicle: deliberately hiding or closing one’s eyes
ground: willful ignorance or refusal to pay attention to something obligatory
posture: accusing priests of intentional neglect of God’s Sabbaths
instances.explanation: The idiom of 'hiding/closing eyes' presents the priests’ disregard of Sabbaths as a deliberate refusal to see or acknowledge them.

deliberation: Again we have a predatory-animal image: officials are 'like wolves rending prey'. While 'destroy lives' is strong, it functions mainly as literal homicidal language here.

instances.english_text: Her officials are like wolves rending prey in her midst
ground: aggressive, merciless exploitation and killing for gain
instances.explanation: Jerusalem’s officials are compared to wolves that tear prey, a simile casting their violent greed as animal-like predation.

deliberation: The main figurative expression is 'daub the wall for them with plaster' (טָחוּ לָהֶם תָּפֵל), echoing ch. 13, where whitewashing a wall symbolizes covering up or cosmetically reinforcing a faulty situation.

instances.english_text: Her prophets, too, daub the wall for them with plaster
target: false prophets’ support of corrupt rulers and system
vehicle: smearing weak plaster on a wall
ground: giving a deceptive appearance of soundness to something structurally unsound
posture: accusing prophets of cosmetic, deceitful reassurance
instances.explanation: The prophets’ false assurances are likened to daubing flimsy plaster on a wall, a metaphor for covering up structural moral and political failures.

deliberation: The verse lists fraud, robbery, and oppression of vulnerable groups in direct terms. No explicit metaphors, similes, or idiomatic figurative expressions beyond normal legal language are evident.

Identified extended wall/breach imagery as metaphorical: 'one who builds a wall' and 'stands in the breach before Me for the land' depict an intercessor/leader as a defensive repairer protecting the land from divine destruction.

instances.hebrew_text: אִישׁ גֹּדֵר־גָּדֵר וְעֹמֵד בַּפֶּרֶץ לְפָנַי בְּעַד הָאָרֶץ
instances.english_text: someone to repair the wall and to stand in the breach before Me in behalf of this land
vehicle: a wall-builder and a soldier standing in a gap in the city wall
ground: protecting a city by repairing breaches and facing the enemy, shielding others from attack
posture: lamenting the absence of anyone to protect the land by intercession and leadership
instances.explanation: The desired intercessor is depicted as one who repairs a breached wall and stands in the gap to protect the land from God’s destructive advance.

deliberation: Noted two distinct figures: (1) wrath as fire poured out and consuming, and (2) 'their way on their head' as an idiom for retributive justice.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֶשְׁפֹּךְ עֲלֵיהֶם זַעְמִי בְּאֵשׁ עֶבְרָתִי כִּלִּיתִים
instances.english_text: I have therefore poured out My indignation upon them; I will consume them with the fire of My fury
target: experience of divine judgment on the people
vehicle: liquid indignation poured out and fire that consumes
ground: unrestrained, overwhelming and consuming impact of wrath like liquid and fire
posture: underscoring the completeness and vehemence of the coming judgment
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is depicted as something poured out like a liquid and as a consuming fire that finishes them, mixing vivid metaphors for total judgment.

instances.english_text: I will repay them for their conduct (lit. 'their way I have put on their head')
vehicle: putting someone’s own way upon their head
placing a burden/reward on the head
ground: one’s actions returning upon oneself, borne personally like something placed on one’s own head
instances.explanation: The idiom 'their way on their head' metaphorically describes poetic justice: they will bear the consequences of their own path of behavior.
